citation.article-title: Shewanella denitrificans sp. nov., a vigorously denitrifying bacterium isolated from the oxic-anoxic interface of the Gotland Deep in the central Baltic Sea.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Shewanella denitrificans sp. nov.
Shewanella denitrificans (de.ni.tri'fi.cans. N.L. v. denitrifico to denitrify; N.L. part. adj. denitrificans denitrifying, referring to the capacity for vigorous denitrification)
Cells are Gram-negative, polarly flagellated with two flagella, rod-shaped (straight or curved rods: width, 0.5-0.8 μm; length, 2.0-3.0 μm) and oxidase- and catalase-positive.
Colonies are circular, transparent and unpigmented to slightly yellow or brownish on ZoBell agar or marine agar.
Growth is facultatively anaerobic, chemoheterotrophic and occurs at 4-30 °C, with optimum growth at 20-25 °C.
Sugars such as glucose are not metabolized with production of acid.
Dominant fatty acids are 16:1ω7c, 15:0 iso, 16:0 and 13:0 iso.
NaCl supports growth, but is not required for growth; strains do not tolerate high salinity (>6%).
Growth occurs under anoxic conditions in the presence of nitrate, nitrite and sulphite, but not in the presence of trimethylaminoxide, ferric iron or thiosulphate as electron acceptors.
Able to use an ample spectrum of carbohydrates such as D-glucose, N-acetylglucosamine, aesculin, maltose, starch and glycogen.
β-Glucosidase, protease, aminopeptidase, phosphatase (alkaline) and leucine arylamidase activities are present.
Starch, gelatin, Tween 80 and lecithin are hydrolysed.
The G+C content ranges from 46.8 to 48.1 mol%.
The type strain is strain OS217T (=DSM 15013T=LMG 21692T).
